content: Entire hillsides are covered with wind turbines in Mojave, California quote: US trains green workers of the future But in Tehachapi, California, they mean four seasons in one day. In this remote corner between the Sierra Nevada and the Mojave Desert, it can feel like summer one hour, winter the next. And the weather is propelled by strong winds that man has put to use - entire hillsides are covered by wind turbines. This is a pioneering place for the US's wind power industry and it is where engineers of the future learn their trade. Massive expansion We joined some young students from nearby Cerro Coso Community College as an industry professional guided them on their first climb of an 80ft (27m) wind turbine tower. It is part of a course where they learn the mechanical, practical and safety skills needed to maintain and fix wind turbines. They have each paid around $1,000 (£684): for young men barely out of their teens that is a lot, but they believe it will pay off with stable jobs and salaries that can start at up to three times the national minimum wage. And the jobs will be there. The economic stimulus package recently passed by the US Congress includes money to make people's homes more energy efficient. National benchmark It is part of a much bigger plan: President Obama wants to spend $150bn over 10 years on a massive expansion of renewable energy. He says it will cut the country's dependance on foreign oil, create five "green-collar" jobs and help tackle climate change. (....) It's a start..... +http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7959667.stm
quote: US trains green workers of the future But in Tehachapi, California, they mean four seasons in one day. In this remote corner between the Sierra Nevada and the Mojave Desert, it can feel like summer one hour, winter the next. And the weather is propelled by strong winds that man has put to use - entire hillsides are covered by wind turbines. This is a pioneering place for the US's wind power industry and it is where engineers of the future learn their trade. Massive expansion We joined some young students from nearby Cerro Coso Community College as an industry professional guided them on their first climb of an 80ft (27m) wind turbine tower. It is part of a course where they learn the mechanical, practical and safety skills needed to maintain and fix wind turbines. They have each paid around $1,000 (£684): for young men barely out of their teens that is a lot, but they believe it will pay off with stable jobs and salaries that can start at up to three times the national minimum wage. And the jobs will be there. The economic stimulus package recently passed by the US Congress includes money to make people's homes more energy efficient. National benchmark It is part of a much bigger plan: President Obama wants to spend $150bn over 10 years on a massive expansion of renewable energy. He says it will cut the country's dependance on foreign oil, create five "green-collar" jobs and help tackle climate change. (....)
reply: Entire hillsides are covered with wind turbines in Mojave, California  It's a start..... +http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7959667.stm

content: quote: Only major project that i see at this time is nuclear power plants across the nation and the permanent jobs they will create. Now who could be stopping that when its so obvious thats whats needed? More Nukes, fewer Kooks! I've been saying that for years. To answer your question as to who is stopping them let's go back to who stopped them to begin with. It was President Carter that put the kibosh on the atom. I find that strange considering he was a nuclear engineer and served on atomic submarines. Obviously he knew the benefit of nuclear power and he also knew, properly built and run they're safe. That being the case the only reasonable explanation is that he was swayed by some unknown force. What makes it so sad is that with American know how, had we been allowed to go forward with nuclear power generation, by now the nuclear situation would be very different. Two main factors are most important in considering whether or not to build a grid of nuclear generating stations. The first is safety. Horror stories like The Chernobyl disaster rightfully frighten people. Chernobyl was a poorly built incompletely run accident waiting to happen. There is no comparison between the crude reactors Russia produced and the well designed, carefully built reactors produced here. The very worst incident to take place at any American reactor occurred at the Three Mile Island generating station. There was a small amount of radioactive steam released. The maximum amount of radiation anyone was exposed to was about the amount received during a full set of dental x-rays. Sadly the incident was blown out of proportion by the news hungry media. The second factor is that of “hot ash” disposal. It’s true that our current reactors do produce significant amounts of radioactive waste. Had we been allowed to go forth, by now at the very least we’d be building Breeder reactors that produce no hot ash. It’s even possible that, by now we would have such things as Fusan reactors that would be far more efficient and cheaper to build. All of this was short circuited by President Carter for reasons, unknown. Sorry to be so long winded but y'all hit on one of my pet subjects. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?
quote: Only major project that i see at this time is nuclear power plants across the nation and the permanent jobs they will create. Now who could be stopping that when its so obvious thats whats needed?

Obviously he knew the benefit of nuclear power and he also knew, properly built and run they're safe. That being the case the only reasonable explanation is that he was swayed by some unknown force. What makes it so sad is that with American know how, had we been allowed to go forward with nuclear power generation, by now the nuclear situation would be very different. Two main factors are most important in considering whether or not to build a grid of nuclear generating stations. The first is safety. Horror stories like The Chernobyl disaster rightfully frighten people. Chernobyl was a poorly built incompletely run accident waiting to happen. There is no comparison between the crude reactors Russia produced and the well designed, carefully built reactors produced here. The very worst incident to take place at any American reactor occurred at the Three Mile Island generating station. There was a small amount of radioactive steam released. The maximum amount of radiation anyone was exposed to was about the amount received during a full set of dental x-rays. Sadly the incident was blown out of proportion by the news hungry media. The second factor is that of “hot ash” disposal. It’s true that our current reactors do produce significant amounts of radioactive waste. Had we been allowed to go forth, by now at the very least we’d be building Breeder reactors that produce no hot ash. It’s even possible that, by now we would have such things as Fusan reactors that would be far more efficient and cheaper to build. All of this was short circuited by President Carter for reasons, unknown. Sorry to be so long winded but y'all hit on one of my pet subjects. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?

content: This statement from the link is so very true! quote: The Nano should make global automakers stop loading their cars with costly gadgets people don’t really want, he added. I looked at getting a new truck and they don't even offer one with a standard transmission any more. I don't need or want heated leather power seats or power anything. Nore do I want an auto transmission with electric shift for 4 wheel drive. I opted to keep driving the one I have with most of the basics only. I refuse to be forced to buy a loaded truck that is used to work instead of play.
quote: The Nano should make global automakers stop loading their cars with costly gadgets people don’t really want, he added.

I opted to keep driving the one I have with most of the basics only. I refuse to be forced to buy a loaded truck that is used to work instead of play.

I find that strange considering he was a nuclear engineer and served on atomic submarines. Obviously he knew the benefit of nuclear power and he also knew, properly built and run they're safe. That being the case the only reasonable explanation is that he was swayed by some unknown force. What makes it so sad is that with American know how, had we been allowed to go forward with nuclear power generation, by now the nuclear situation would be very different. Two main factors are most important in considering whether or not to build a grid of nuclear generating stations. The first is safety. Horror stories like The Chernobyl disaster rightfully frighten people. Chernobyl was a poorly built incompletely run accident waiting to happen. There is no comparison between the crude reactors Russia produced and the well designed, carefully built reactors produced here. The very worst incident to take place at any American reactor occurred at the Three Mile Island generating station. There was a small amount of radioactive steam released. The maximum amount of radiation anyone was exposed to was about the amount received during a full set of dental x-rays. Sadly the incident was blown out of proportion by the news hungry media. The second factor is that of “hot ash” disposal. It’s true that our current reactors do produce significant amounts of radioactive waste. Had we been allowed to go forth, by now at the very least we’d be building Breeder reactors that produce no hot ash. It’s even possible that, by now we would have such things as Fusan reactors that would be far more efficient and cheaper to build. All of this was short circuited by President Carter for reasons, unknown. Sorry to be so long winded but y'all hit on one of my pet subjects. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?
quote: Only major project that i see at this time is nuclear power plants across the nation and the permanent jobs they will create. Now who could be stopping that when its so obvious thats whats needed?
reply: More Nukes, fewer Kooks! I've been saying that for years. To answer your question as to who is stopping them let's go back to who stopped them to begin with. It was President Carter that put the kibosh on the atom. I find that strange considering he was a nuclear engineer and served on atomic submarines. Obviously he knew the benefit of nuclear power and he also knew, properly built and run they're safe. That being the case the only reasonable explanation is that he was swayed by some unknown force. What makes it so sad is that with American know how, had we been allowed to go forward with nuclear power generation, by now the nuclear situation would be very different. Two main factors are most important in considering whether or not to build a grid of nuclear generating stations. The first is safety. Horror stories like The Chernobyl disaster rightfully frighten people. Chernobyl was a poorly built incompletely run accident waiting to happen. There is no comparison between the crude reactors Russia produced and the well designed, carefully built reactors produced here. The very worst incident to take place at any American reactor occurred at the Three Mile Island generating station. There was a small amount of radioactive steam released. The maximum amount of radiation anyone was exposed to was about the amount received during a full set of dental x-rays. Sadly the incident was blown out of proportion by the news hungry media. The second factor is that of “hot ash” disposal. It’s true that our current reactors do produce significant amounts of radioactive waste. Had we been allowed to go forth, by now at the very least we’d be building Breeder reactors that produce no hot ash. It’s even possible that, by now we would have such things as Fusan reactors that would be far more efficient and cheaper to build. All of this was short circuited by President Carter for reasons, unknown. Sorry to be so long winded but y'all hit on one of my pet subjects. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?

content: quote: Originally posted by dmuhler: quote: Originally posted by bill_kananen: quote: dmuhler: A Lot of people live without cars. That's just BS. Some people do but not a lot. content: This statement from the link is so very true! quote: The Nano should make global automakers stop loading their cars with costly gadgets people don’t really want, he added. I looked at getting a new truck and they don't even offer one with a standard transmission any more. I don't need or want heated leather power seats or power anything. Nore do I want an auto transmission with electric shift for 4 wheel drive. I opted to keep driving the one I have with most of the basics only. I refuse to be forced to buy a loaded truck that is used to work instead of play.
